text:
today on hot Thai kitchen we're making larb moo 
sawadee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today I'm

taking you to Eastern or northeastern Thailand 
and making one of their iconic dishes we're

making lot now a larb is a name but it's also 
a cooking technique so you can say I want to

have some chicken and want to have some duck 
today we're going to larb some pork and larb

is a warm salad made up of ground meat let's get 
started so first let's make the most important

ingredient in this dish toasted rice powder 
without this it's not a lot so what we have

here is one and a half tablespoons of sticky rice 
raw sticky rice you can do this with jasmine rice

as well but traditionally that's what they use 
in a dry saute pan you're just going to I think

it's this one you're just going to toast it on 
medium high heat and you want to keep it moving

and what you're looking for is for it to start 
turning golden brown okay so that's pretty much

what you're looking for a deep golden brown and 
now it's going to smell it's going to add a very

nice toasty aroma that's very unique to this dish 
now we're going to grind this up into a powder and

you can use a coffee grinder or you can use a 
heavy duty mortar and pestle like this one here

and just going to start pounding now only make 
as much as you need because the fragrance is very

fleeting unless you're going to use in the next 
few days or within the week I would just make only

as much as you will need today and just make it 
again next time it's really easy and fast to make

so this is what you kind of are going for nice 
and fine nothing too big and it's actually easier

to do like a round round motion than to do this 
okay so we've got that next let's do our ground

meet raising ground for today and what I got 
here in this pot is two tablespoons of water

then I'm going to bring to a boil so once your 
waters come to a boil I'm going to add 250 grams

of ground pork that's about nine ounces and then 
we're just going to cook this now this technique

is called everyone and it's a technique of 
cooking just ground meat in some water and

I think the reason why you don't use oil is 
because Isan is actually a very poor part of

Thailand and so water is cheaper than oil so if 
you can make something cook with water why not

right okay so our pork is done now we're just 
going to turn this off and then move this over

to our mixing area now this is a one pot dish 
so this will actually be our mixing bowl right

here so to this I'm going to add about three 
tablespoons of thinly sliced sliced shallots

stir it in a little bit just to break up the rings 
and also to wilt the shallots to take away some of

that raw pungent flavor and then to this our 
seasoning have two tablespoons of fish sauce

one two tablespoons of lime juice 
a bunch of chili flakes however

much you want it's up to you and then our 
rice powder about a tablespoon and a half

okay quarter cup of chopped mint Leafs 
pluck roughly chop the little ones you

can leave whole two tablespoons of cilantro 
1 tablespoon of green onion and that's it

now all you got to do is mix everything 
out and sir she's probably tasted too

perfect so you can serve this with 
sticky rice some papaya salad some

barbeque chicken or just have it with 
some lettuce like lettuce wrap style

some all that juice is all good you 
can soak that up with extra sticky

rice garnish it with cute little mint 
leaves and a couple of fried dry chilies

and there you go this is lot more thanks 
for tuning in and for full written recipe

visit Hawkeye kitchen calm and we will 
see you next time for next delicious time
